awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Theoretical prediction of wake lock-in for fluid-structure interactions with phase-reduction analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
When a fluid flow interacts with a non-streamlined object, such as a bridge, smokestack, or cable, a wake is created consisting of periodically shed vortices. These vortices exert unsteady forces on the object resulting in structural oscillations with the potential to damage or cause destruction under certain conditions. An especially dangerous situation results when the vortex shedding frequency is close to the resonant frequency of the object. In this case, the vortex shedding synchronizes with the object’s natural frequency and lock-in occurs. Currently, there is no theoretical approach capable of predicting the onset of lock-in. The objective of this experimental and theoretical study is to predict conditions when lock-in occurs on a cylinder oscillating in a fluid flow by focusing on the shedding phase of the vortices relative to the cylinder motion. This research effort will expose high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students to experimental and computational fluid dynamics research. Moreover, the findings will be disseminated to domestic and international research communities through conferences and workshops.

The goal of this project is to predict the occurrence of lock-in using the phase reduction analysis for an oscillating cylinder undergoing coupled translational and rotational motion. The project will involve complementary experimental and theoretical work focusing on (i) generating the required phase-response functions needed to predict the synchronization condition, (ii) theoretically predicting and verifying the required translational and rotational forced oscillations required to expand or collapse the synchronization region, and (iii) consider higher-order nonlinear terms in the analysis to more accurately capture synchronization that occurs for larger amplitude oscillations. These tasks will be undertaken through experimental efforts using hot-film thermal anemometry to measure changes to the vortex shedding frequency caused by small perturbation and large oscillatory forced motions. On the computational side, direct numerical simulations will be performed to capture the wake dynamics and force history on the body under forced vibrations. The force histories from computations will be used to reveal the synchronization properties and then be compared to the measured shedding frequencies to verify the theoretical predictions. The overall effort is expected to support controlling the occurrence of lock-in by eliminating the synchronization region and suppress vortex-induced vibrations. Furthermore, it would allow the expansion of the synchronization region which would result in more efficient flow control, chemical mixing, and energy harvesting. High school students with the aim to motivate them to pursue careers in science and engineering fields and to increase their knowledge in scientific research.  The undergraduate research activities will provide unique opportunities to train students to prepare for advanced engineering careers in the industry, government, and academia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of the experimental and computational study was to validate our approach of analyzing the periodic wake dynamics using phase-reduction analysis to predict wake synchronization for an oscillating bluff body. The present work was a joint theoretical, computational, and experimental effort to examine the validity of phase-reduction analysis in physical fluid flows and to quantify the influence of noise and nonlinearities on the robustness of the overall approach. The experimental and theoretical foundations from this work provides a foundation for a systematic study of VIV and the development of physics-driven vibration suppression using phase-reduction models. Initially, verification and validation of phase-sensitivity analysis for 2D and 3D cylinder wakes in forced vibrations were completed. Furthermore, an adjoint-based phase-sensitivity algorithm was developed and applied to examine bluff body wakes and vortex formation. Once the methodology was validated, the team focused on 3D phase-reduction analysis and uncovered the influence of 3D vortical flow structures on the ability of a bluff body to synchronize with forced vibrations. Moreover, the optimal waveform for synchronization was also found using theoretical analysis, which paves the way for efficient transient control. The experimental effort explored the feasibility of generating phase-response functions using various magnitude impulses over a range of lower Reynolds numbers. The studies identified the minimal forcing input that still produced a measurable phase shift. We also experimentally determined laminar wake phase-sensitivity function for crossflow and rotary motion using the ensemble-based averaging approach developed herein. The team also experimentally identified the lower frequency and higher frequency branches of the synchronization region and compared their boundaries to the boundaries predicted by phase-reduction analysis. They performed this comparison for both crossflow and rotary motion using sinusoidal profiles. To look at the affect of the motion profile on synchronization, they also looked at the boundaries for a sawtooth profile for crossflow motion. The team also confirmed, through experiments, the ability to greatly reduce the size of the synchronization region through the appropriate coupling of crossflow and rotary motion, as predicted by phase-reduction analysis. Finally, the experimental effort demonstrated the ability to generate a phase-sensitivity function in a three-dimensional wake at high Reynolds number.

The experimental and theoretical foundations from this work enables a systematic study of the onset of vortex-induced vibrations (VIV) and the development of physics-driven vibration suppression using phase-reduction models in future follow-up studies. PI Klamo participated annually in the Office of Naval Research's Science and Engineering Apprenticeship Program (SEAP) that allows high-school students to work in a Department of Navy laboratory over the summer.  During these three years, four students from local Monterey high schools performed summer internships at NPS supporting the project by performing solid modeling, 3D printing, data collection, and data analysis. During the third year of this effort, PI Klamo also mentored a college student through the Office of Naval Research's Naval Research Enterprise Internship Program (NREIP). The two NPS graduate students, that used this project for their M.S. thesis research, are now serving the U.S. Navy as a naval aviator and a submarine officer. Finally, one of the SEAP summer interns used the lab equipment and water tunnel to perform testing as part of his senior year science project the following school year. Co-PI Taira has worked closely with undergraduate students as research assistants, in addition to graduate student supervision.During this project, UCLA undergraduate and graduate students conducted outreach educational activities at local elementary and high schools in the Los Angeles Unified School District to promote STEM focusing on fluid dynamics.  Moreover, PI Taira organized a US-Japan workshop on data-driven fluid dynamics, where results from phase-reduction analysis were disseminated. This project supported disseminating our findings through three journal papers (with another one about to be submitted for review), twelve conference presentations, two M.S. theses, and one Ph.D. dissertation.


Last Modified: 12/19/2024
Modified by: Kunihiko Taira
